Ok who ever thought that u can not dissolve that type of salt does not not know basic chemistry, when i saw basic chemistry i mean 5 year's olds know that. Firstly most salts are soluble in water due to waters electonegativity. Due to huge difference between the electronegativity between oxygen and hydrogen it makes it a huge candidate for dissolving salts. This is becuase water is classified as a polar substance, and polar substances generally are perfect fpr dissolving salts. While oils and ethonal are not perfect candidates, due to their polrity. Oil and ethonal are classified as non polar substances. Yes u can dissolve salt in oil and ethonal but at a particular temperature, thus making it a generally bad candidate for dissolving salts.

Thumbs up for the Veritaseum reference (and I think you probably got some ions from the melted one, since the main barrier to ionization of sodium and chloride ions from salt is a high energy threshold, and you certainly poured a lot of energy into that salt!), but you might want to watch that video again if you still think that negative ions actually have any noticeable effect. The conclusion wasn't that salt lamps don't emit awesome negative ions, but that salt lamps don't emit ions and ions don't actually have any significant effect.

Also, I realize this is beyond the scope of your video, but if salt lamps really did emit negative ions, then they'd have to have positive ions remaining on the surface, most likely combined with hydroxide ions, forming sodium hydroxide (lye) on the surface of the lamp, given that it's supposed to be water in the air breaking the salt into ions with the addition of heat... which means that the chlorine wouldn't be released as independent chloride ions, but as hydrogen chloride, a colorless gas also known as hydrochloric acid when dissolved in water, so, yeah, probably for the best that those salt lamps don't work.

Rock Salt is essentially the same as normal salt in it's composition, being Sodium Chloride (NaCl). Salt is 'deliquescent', meaning that it absorbs moisture from the atmosphere.
